title: Make BD/PL template-free (no required memory template)
description:
## Outcome

- Updated `PL` and `BD` Codex prompts to be **template-free**: they no longer require a repo to have `.beads/templates/memory.yaml`.
- Updated global Codex agent guidance to treat `memory` as optional (use if present; otherwise create beads with explicit `description`/`design`/`acceptance`).

## Why

Custom bd templates are per-repo. A global planning prompt that assumes a `memory` template becomes brittle across repos. Template-free creation keeps planning flows reliable everywhere while preserving the “beads as memory” quality bar.

## Where (paths / systems)

- Path(s): `codex/prompts/PL.md`, `codex/prompts/BD.md`, `codex/AGENTS.md`
- Component(s): Codex custom prompts + global agent workflow

## Verification (exact commands + results)

- `rg -n "Do \*\*not\*\* assume any custom templates exist" codex/prompts/PL.md codex/prompts/BD.md`
- `rg -n "create beads template-free" codex/prompts/PL.md codex/prompts/BD.md`
design:
## Decisions + rationale

- Keep `memory` templates **optional**: when present, they reduce typing; when absent, prompts still work.
- Prefer portability: a prompt should never break because a repo hasn’t committed a template.

## Alternatives considered

- Auto-seed `.beads/templates/memory.yaml` into repos (self-healing templates): useful, but can be intrusive (writes files in repos that may not want committed `.beads/`).
- Hard-require templates everywhere: rejected; brittle and breaks planning in new repos.

## Constraints / invariants / gotchas

- Multi-line `--description/--design/--acceptance` arguments are shell-quoting-sensitive; prefer `$(cat file)` or `bd edit` when actually running the commands.

## Follow-ups

- If you want the “self-healing” behavior later, add an explicit step to `PL`/`BD`: check `bd template list --json` and, if missing, create or copy the template.
acceptance_criteria:
- [ ] `codex/prompts/PL.md` and `codex/prompts/BD.md` no longer require `--from-template memory`
- [ ] `codex/AGENTS.md` instructs: use `memory` template if present, otherwise create template-free with explicit fields
notes:
- Outcome: Made `PL`/`BD` prompts template-free; `memory` template is optional.
- Key learnings: bd templates are per-repo; global prompts must not assume template existence.
- Decisions + rationale: Keep template path as an optimization (if available), but always provide a non-template command path.
- Constraints / invariants discovered: For durability across repos, prompts should avoid repo-local prerequisites.
- Verification (exact commands + results): `rg -n "Do \*\*not\*\* assume any custom templates exist" codex/prompts/PL.md codex/prompts/BD.md`

title: Make closure notes syncable (use notes, not comments)
description:
We discovered `bd export` does not include issue comments in `.beads/issues.jsonl`, so closure notes stored as comments will not sync across machines.

Update the bead-as-memory workflow to store Closure Notes in an exported field (`notes`) instead of comments, and adjust the warm-start guidance accordingly.
design:
Approach:
- Switch the mandatory closeout step from `bd comments add` to `bd update --notes`.
- Keep comments as optional scratch (local-only), but require distilling into `notes` before closing.
- Warm-start: `bd show` is sufficient because it includes `notes`; `bd comments` becomes optional.
acceptance_criteria:
- `codex/AGENTS.md` mandates Closure Notes in `notes` (not comments)
- `codex/AGENTS.md` warm-start instructions do not require `bd comments`
- `.beads/templates/memory.yaml` aligns (acceptance mentions notes, not comments)
notes:
Outcome:
- Updated `codex/AGENTS.md` to require Closure Notes in the exported `notes` field (not comments).
- Updated warm-start guidance to rely on `bd show` (which includes `notes`).
- Updated `.beads/templates/memory.yaml` and `codex/prompts/GS.md` to match the new notes-based workflow.

Key learnings:
- `bd export` does not include issue comments in `.beads/issues.jsonl`.
- `bd update --notes ...` *is* exported and will sync via `.beads/issues.jsonl`.

Decisions + rationale:
- Treat comments as local scratch only; require distillation into `notes`/`description`/`design` before closing.

Constraints / invariants discovered:
- None.

- In a temp bd repo: added a comment + notes, ran `bd export`, confirmed JSONL included `notes` but not comments.

title: BD prompt: add --parent subtask guidance
description:
## Outcome

- BD prompt now explicitly recommends using `bd create --parent <epic-id>` to create hierarchical child beads under epics.

## Why

design:

- Add `parent-child` links after creation with `bd dep add ... -t parent-child`: works, but is easier to forget and adds steps.

## Constraints / invariants / gotchas

- Do not create docs-only beads; doc work remains embedded in each bead.

## Follow-ups

title: Parameterize GS prompt inputs
description:
## Outcome (fill/update at close)

- Parameterized the `GS` prompt so you can pass a skill request as positional arguments (via `$ARGUMENTS`).
- Added prompt frontmatter metadata (`description`, `argument-hint`) for the Codex slash prompt UI.

## Why

Make `/prompts:GS ...` usable as a real command: the request you type becomes part of the prompt.

## Where (paths / systems)

- [x] Component(s): Codex custom prompts (`~/.codex/prompts/*.md`)

## Verification (exact commands + results)

## Additional Context

Also removed an accidental escaped quote in an example command (`rg -n \"<keyword>\"`).
design:
## Decisions + rationale

- Use `$ARGUMENTS` (positional args) instead of named placeholders so the prompt works with zero required variables.

## Alternatives considered

- Named placeholders like `$SPEC` or `$NAME`: rejected because Codex requires all named placeholders to be provided.

## Constraints / invariants / gotchas

- Avoid introducing accidental `$PLACEHOLDER` tokens in the prompt body (Codex will treat them as placeholders).

## Follow-ups

- None.

- Codex prompt placeholders support `$1`–`$9`, `$ARGUMENTS`, and named `KEY=value` placeholders.
- Named placeholders become required if referenced; `$ARGUMENTS` keeps the prompt usable without mandatory inputs.

title: Migrate bd prefix to dot-free df-
description:
## Outcome

- Renamed this repo’s bd issue prefix from `.dotfiles-*` → `df-*`.
- Removed “orphaned child issue” warnings that were triggered by the leading `.` in issue IDs.
- Forced a fresh `.beads/issues.jsonl` export after rename so git-tracked JSONL matches the database.

## Why

A leading `.` in issue IDs caused bd’s orphan/hierarchy detection to mis-classify issues. A dot-free prefix makes bd output clean and avoids confusing warnings.

## Where (paths / systems)

- Systems: bd database + `.beads/issues.jsonl`
- Path(s): `.beads/issues.jsonl`

## Verification (exact commands + results)

- `bd config list --json` (no orphan warning; `issue_prefix` is `df`)
- `rg -n '"id":"\\.dotfiles-' .beads/issues.jsonl` (no matches)
design:
## Decisions + rationale

- Use the shortest dot-free prefix (`df-`) that still indicates “dotfiles”.
- Prefer `bd rename-prefix` (built-in) over ad-hoc JSONL editing to ensure all references are updated safely.

## Alternatives considered

- Keep `.dotfiles-*` and ignore warnings: rejected; warnings degrade trust and signal false problems.
- Choose a longer prefix like `dotfiles-`: rejected; exceeds bd’s max prefix length.

## Constraints / invariants / gotchas

- `bd export` may refuse after ID migrations due to “stale DB” safety checks; use `--force` only when you’re intentionally overwriting an out-of-date JSONL with current DB state.

## Follow-ups

- Consider rewriting any historical bead text that mentions `.dotfiles-*` if you want search/grep consistency (optional).
acceptance_criteria:
- [ ] `bd config list --json` shows `issue_prefix` = `df` and prints no orphan detection warnings
- [ ] `.beads/issues.jsonl` contains only `df-*` issue IDs
notes:
- Outcome: Migrated issue IDs from `.dotfiles-*` to `df-*` via `bd rename-prefix df-`.
- Key learnings: Leading `.` in the prefix can trip bd’s hierarchy/orphan detection; dot-free prefix avoids noisy false warnings.
- Decisions + rationale: Used `df-` (short, dot-free, within bd prefix rules). Used `bd rename-prefix` to update IDs + references safely.
- Constraints / invariants discovered: After rename, `bd export` may refuse due to safety checks; `bd export -o .beads/issues.jsonl --force` is appropriate when JSONL is known stale.
- Verification (exact commands + results): `bd config list --json`; `rg -n '"id":"\\.dotfiles-' .beads/issues.jsonl`

title: PL/BD: self-seed memory template when missing
description:
## Outcome

- Updated `BD` to detect whether the `memory` template exists and seed `.beads/templates/memory.yaml` when missing.
- Updated `PL` to require the same seeding step (referencing the canonical template content in `BD`).

## Why

bd templates are per-repo. If `PL`/`BD` assume `memory` exists, planning breaks in repos that haven’t committed `.beads/templates/memory.yaml`. Self-seeding makes the workflow portable while still producing memory-rich beads.

## Where (paths / systems)

- Path(s): `codex/prompts/BD.md`, `codex/prompts/PL.md`
- Component(s): Codex custom prompts; bd templates

## Verification (exact commands + results)

- `rg -n "Ensure the `memory` template exists" codex/prompts/BD.md codex/prompts/PL.md`
- `rg -n "cat > \\.beads/templates/memory\\.yaml" codex/prompts/BD.md`
design:
## Decisions + rationale

- Keep a 3-tier robustness ladder:
  1) Use `memory` template if present.
  2) Seed it if missing.
  3) Fall back to template-free `bd create --description/--design/--acceptance` if seeding isn’t possible.

## Alternatives considered

- Hard-require templates everywhere: rejected (brittle).
- Template-free only: acceptable, but seeding reduces friction and encourages consistent bead structure.

## Constraints / invariants / gotchas

- Seeding only helps other agents/clones if `.beads/templates/*.yaml` is committed; some repos may need `.gitignore` exceptions.
acceptance_criteria:

- [ ] `codex/prompts/PL.md` instructs to seed the template before creating beads
notes:
- Outcome: `BD`/`PL` can self-seed the `memory` template so planning doesn’t depend on repo-local setup.
- Key learnings: bd templates are per-repo; portability requires either seeding or template-free commands.
- Decisions + rationale: Prefer seeding (for consistent structure) but always keep a template-free fallback.

Outcome:
- Added new prompt `GS` at `codex/prompts/GS.md` for generating Codex/Claude-style compatible skills.

Key learnings:
- Codex skills are discovered only from `~/.codex/skills/**/SKILL.md` and loaded once at startup.
- Frontmatter requirements are minimal but strict: YAML `name` (<=100 chars) and `description` (<=500 chars), both one-line; extra keys are ignored.
- `bd show` doesn’t include comments; for “memory” use-cases, ensure your warm-start loads comments too (handled separately in AGENTS guidance).

Decisions + rationale:
- Provide a single prompt that covers both creating and upgrading skills.
- Encourage “skill packs” only when there are multiple independent sub-workflows (gateway + INDEX + sub-skill docs).
- Include a canonical validation step (restart Codex) plus an optional fast preflight script.
